utterances.speaker: SILK
utterances.sentences: And stop allowing them to hoodwink us. You know, they ran on changing or doing something or redoing something with healthcare because they gave us Obamacare and have done absolutely nothing about it. This is exactly what the Democrats do. They like to hoodwink people, make you think they're going to do this for you when they do nothing but fill you a bill of empty promises.

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.sentences: They all talk and no action.

utterances.speaker: SILK
utterances.sentences: That's right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All right, speaking of Maxine Waters. A lot of talk, a lot a lot of talk from her recently. This again is about her favorite topic, impeachment. Go ahead.

utterances.speaker: REP. MAXINE WATERS, D-CALIF.
utterances.sentences: I believe that this President is dangerous. I think he has undermined our democracy. I think he's aligned himself with the enemy, with Putin. He loves dictators and I believe that he certainly qualifies for impeachment.

utterances.speaker: D. TRUMP
utterances.sentences: It's called Presidential harassment. The President of your country is doing a great job, but he's being harassed. It's Presidential harassment.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Presidential harassment. Do you think that's what this is? This impeachment deal?

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.sentences: That's exactly what it is.

utterances.speaker: SILK
utterances.sentences: That's right.

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.sentences: You know, there's a slush fund up there with Congress where they're paying off people that have been - these congressmen that have been accused of sexual harassment or sexual misconduct.

utterances.speaker: SILK
utterances.sentences: That's right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.sentences: Or sexual misconduct.

utterances.speaker: SILK
utterances.sentences: That's right.

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.sentences: They are paying them off with our tax dollars.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, they are.

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.sentences: What about that slush fund? Why don't you - why don't Maxine Waters go and harass those people. We want to see the names of these Congress men and women or whoever who are accused of these --

utterances.speaker: SILK
utterances.sentences: That's right. Who did we pay?

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.sentences: We need to see that. I am tired of them talking I'm talking about impeachment. Impeach him for what? For giving us a booming economy? That's why you want to impeach him?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: There's no money for the wall, but there's money to pay off all the people that Congress harassed.

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.sentences: There you go.

utterances.speaker: SILK
utterances.sentences: That's right, and it's our taxpayers' money that's doing it. We can use that money to fund the wall.

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.sentences: And what are you going to impeach him on? Or impeach him for? If we're going to impeach anybody, let's start with her because we went to her district.

utterances.speaker: SILK
utterances.sentences: We went to her district.

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.sentences: It's a hot mess.

utterances.speaker: SILK
utterances.sentences: That's right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All right, Diamond and Silk, in studio, "Chitchat Tour" launching next year, don't miss it.

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SILK
utterances.sentences: Yes. Don't miss it, sweetie.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All right, up next, a body language expert breaks down what really happened at the Trump-Pelosi-Schumer meeting. Stick to it. President Trump opening his contentious meeting on wall funding with Nancy Pelosi and Chuck Schumer to the public. The President telling Schumer he would own a government shutdown if that's what it took to get his wall.

utterances.speaker: D. TRUMP
utterances.sentences: The last time, Chuck, you shut it down.

utterances.speaker: SEN. CHUCK SCHUMER, D-N.Y.
utterances.sentences: No, no, no.

utterances.speaker: D. TRUMP
utterances.sentences: And then you opened it ...

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.sentences: Many times.

utterances.speaker: D. TRUMP
utterances.sentences: ... very quickly. I don't want to do what you did.

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.sentences: Twenty times you have called for - I will shut down the government, if I don't get my wall. None of us --

utterances.speaker: D. TRUMP
utterances.sentences: You want to know something? SCHUMER: You've said it.

utterances.speaker: D. TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Okay, you want to put that on my --

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.sentences: You said it.

utterances.speaker: D. TRUMP
utterances.sentences: I'll take it.

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.sentences: Okay, good.

utterances.speaker: D. TRUMP
utterances.sentences: You know what I'll say, yes, if we don't get what we want, one way or the other whether it's through you, through a military, through anything you want to call, I will shut down the government.

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.sentences: Okay, absolutely, no.

utterances.speaker: D. TRUMP
utterances.sentences: And I am proud and I'll tell you what ...

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.sentences: We disagree.

utterances.speaker: D. TRUMP
utterances.sentences: I am proud to shut down government for border security, Chuck.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: A lot going on right there, particularly with the body language, so expert Tonya Reiman is here to help us out. Hey Tonya.

utterances.speaker: TONYA REIMAN, BODY LANGUAGE EXPERT
utterances.sentences: Hey, how are you?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Very good. All right, let's take a look and slow this down of this interaction between crying Chuck and the President. All right, what are we seeing here?

utterances.speaker: REIMAN
utterances.sentences: Okay, so obviously, we know, President Trump loves to use his hands and he uses them to frame his words, so when you're watching him -- Okay, here's the interesting thing. You see how he just adjusted his jacket.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: REIMAN
utterances.sentences: This is the one time that you see him get nervous. When he adjusts his jacket, that's his little bit of discomfort coming through, but here comes the New York. Okay, so he leans forward, gets closer to Schumer and then the only other pacifying gesture he does is he holds his hand like this. So when you hold your hand like this and you see Schumer is doing the same thing, this is something that builds comfort and it also puts a blockage between the two of us.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's like a soothing.

utterances.speaker: REIMAN
utterances.sentences: Right, not only that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: What's he doing here? Now, he's - oh, with the finger.

utterances.speaker: REIMAN
utterances.sentences: Oh, yes, that's you and Nancy, right? And then again, the stop sign. This is what he's famous for like it's not your turn to talk, it's my turn to talk. Listen to what I'm saying. So a lot has been made also about Schumer with his posture. He's a slouch to begin with. He just has terrible posture. When he got serious though, he lifted himself back up and then went right back into that position. So I love the fact that Trump was so into like right getting into --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, he's right up in Chuck's face.

utterances.speaker: REIMAN
utterances.sentences: Yes, there was no go about.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Now, also, there was some interesting kind of go-between between Nancy Pelosi and the President. Let's watch that.

utterances.speaker: D. TRUMP
utterances.sentences: You know, Nancy is in a situation where it's not easy for her to talk right now and I understand that and I fully understand that. We're going to have a good discussion and we're going to see what happens. But we have to have border security.

utterances.speaker: PELOSI
utterances.sentences: Mr. President, please characterize the strength that I bring for this meeting as the leader of the House Democrats who just won a big victory.

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.sentences: Elections have consequences, Mr. President. PELOSI; Let me just say it.

utterances.speaker: D. TRUMP
utterances.sentences: That's right and that's why the country is doing so well.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All right, so the President starts off and let's look at what he's doing here. He starts off kind of talking for Nancy.

utterances.speaker: REIMAN
utterances.sentences: Okay, look at the steeple.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, what is the steeple when the President does that?

utterances.speaker: REIMAN
utterances.sentences: This is what his go-to position, but a steeple is typically considered to be one of power, so this is his go-to posture.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Okay, got it.

utterances.speaker: REIMAN
utterances.sentences: What was interesting is you see Nancy, she gets very offended and she - don't speak for me. This is a woman no matter you like her or dislike her, she is not afraid of Trump.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: She's doing a lot of aggressive hand motions.

utterances.speaker: REIMAN
utterances.sentences: Yes, because she is not afraid. She is like "don't speak for me.” She came in to have a meeting and gets frustrated because you see Schumer looking at everybody who's in the crowd. You see Trump talking to the crowd and Pence just sitting there. So Pelosi is getting annoyed because she's like "I want to have a dialogue" and that's when she starts to turn around and talk to other people.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Okay, let's look at Pence here. I mean, what is Pence doing the whole time, just like this? What does that - I mean, he's just like "get me out of here."

utterances.speaker: REIMAN
utterances.sentences: Here's the interesting thing. If you watch him, not only did he lean back in his chair which is a distancing thing. We do that we want --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: So he doesn't want any part of this.

utterances.speaker: REIMAN
utterances.sentences: Right, but not only that. He also sways back and forth depending who he agrees with at any given moment.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: He might be agreeing with Nancy.

utterances.speaker: REIMAN
utterances.sentences: Yes, he might just not be agreeing with Trump. There's a difference. It doesn't mean he's agreeing with Nancy.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Very interesting.

utterances.speaker: REIMAN
utterances.sentences: And if you watch him, he does fidget. The foot will start to jazz occasionally.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Jazz foot.

utterances.speaker: REIMAN
utterances.sentences: Yes, and he does not hold eye contact really with anyone. He says what's called an extended eye closure quite often and that's his way of like shutting this out because he truly does not want to be there and it's quite evident.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All right. Tonya Reiman, everybody. Thank you very much.

utterances.speaker: REIMAN
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Coming up next, a "Watters' World" flashback on crooked Hillary. Don't miss this one. "Last Call." I have some good news to share. Some of my classic "Watters' World" interviews are now available on Fox Nation, our new premium subscription service and I've got a sneak peek for you, guys. Here's a look at one of my favorites from last year - no, two years ago actually when I attended a Hillary rally in Philly.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Do you trust Hillary?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Yes, I do. Yes, I do.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Do you think Hillary is a smart woman?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Yes, she is, definitely. She's definitely experienced.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Then why didn't she know that C stood for classified? What was Hillary's greatest accomplishment as Secretary of State?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Actually that is a good question.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Take your time.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Oh honestly, I'm not as informed about her term as Secretary of State.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: So we just really want her to be transparent and for the black community, we here kind of have more of a stance with that, you know.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You want her to be transparent?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Good luck with that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All right, see the rest of this clip as well as the entire first season of classic "Watters' World," so sign up on Fox Nation today. FoxNation.com, trust me, it's definitely worth it. That's all for tonight. Be sure to follow me on Facebook, Instagram and Twitter. "Justice With Judge Jeanine" is up next and remember, I'm Watters' and this is my world. Content and Programming Copyright 2018 Fox News Network, LLC. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED. utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, HOST
utterances.utterance: Welcome to "Watters' World," I'm Jesse Watters. A government shutdown looming as the President fights for his border wall. The President hosting a high-stakes meeting with the Democrat leaders live for all to see demanding $5 billion in wall funding, saying he would own a shutdown if it came down to it.

utterances.speaker: PRESIDENT DONALD TRUMP
utterances.utterance: I will take the mantle. I will be the one to shut it down. I'm not going to blame you for it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Trump adding he would even go around Democrats if they don't deliver the votes to get there. Here to react, counselor to the President, Kellyanne Conway. Merry Christmas, Kellyanne.

utterances.speaker: KELLYANNE CONWAY, COUNSELOR TO THE PRESIDENT
utterances.utterance: Merry Christmas, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right, so do you believe it's risky for the President to own the shutdown? I understand he thinks immigration is a good issue for him. Is it because he sees this as the last chance to get the wall funding until the House maybe flips in 2020?

utterances.speaker: CONWAY
utterances.utterance: This is way beyond immigration or even the wall, this is border security and border security is national security. This President has made clear that his primary duty to all of us in this country, Jesse, is to keep us safe. And we see what happens when you have a porous border. You have poison like fentanyl and heroin and cocaine pouring over. You have people trying to come here illegally, you have people being promised by coyotes and others that they've paid thousands of dollars to, maybe more, promises that cannot be delivered upon and look what's happened to many of those folks trying to come here and this is a President who knows that we as a nation have been spending billions of dollars over decades helping other nations protect their own sovereign borders, it's high time we do it here.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's a great point.

utterances.speaker: CONWAY
utterances.utterance: Now, he also knows that there were 26 Democrats in the Senate who voted for the Secure Fence Act in 2006 and they were none other - and let me just highlight a few for you -- Senator Joe Biden, Senator Barack Obama, Senator Chuck Schumer and Senator ding-ding-ding Hillary Clinton. So what's happened on the border since the 2006 Secure Fence Act was voted on, it got worse. It's more porous, and we're more in danger.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, it's actually - it's interesting, since they started building any sort of fencing wherever they built it, immigration through that area halted and it funnels the foot traffic of the illegals to softer points.

utterances.speaker: CONWAY
utterances.utterance: That's right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So wherever the walls are, the walls work. Let me show you some sound of how the people in the media are framing the border security issue. Listen to this.

utterances.speaker: CHRIS CUOMO, ANCHOR, CNN
utterances.utterance: The President went to the heart of what I call his Brown Menace theory. These migrants, they're dirty people. They bring disease.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: This border wall thing is about controlling the browning of America.

utterances.speaker: ALEXANDRIA OCASIO-CORTEZ, CONGRESSWOMAN-ELECT, D-N.Y.
utterances.utterance: Donald Trump is fixated on the southern border as he was the day that he announced this campaign. It is not about securing the borders. It is about xenophobic, racist, bigoted beliefs.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So the media is racializing border security.

utterances.speaker: CONWAY
utterances.utterance: Always.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: If you look at all of the polls, a majority of Americans, they want border security. They're there against sanctuary cities. They're anti-caravan, but then when you hear people say, "Oh, you want border security, you must be racists." Do you think that's backfiring on the left?

utterances.speaker: CONWAY
utterances.utterance: It does backfire because people are very focused on what the issue at hand here truly is, and it's whether or not you want a Customs and Border Patrol. These brave men and women at the border who say they need enhancements, they need better security. They need electronic enhancements. They need fences. They need walls whether they're concrete or not, they need border security. They're telling us, they're not cosseted on some - and protecting on some fancy TV set in Washington or New York pontificating, they are actually doing the job to keep us all safe.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: This is what pretty nice set, I have to admit.

utterances.speaker: CONWAY
utterances.utterance: And you know, you've got - well, I wasn't talking about you, but yes it is. And by the way this is a pretty nice perch, too, where we're at. But CPB, ICE - all those dum-dums who want to abolish ICE, abolish ICE. Do you know what ICE did just last year, they intercepted and they surveilled enough fentanyl to have killed every man, woman and child in this country. They're stopping the human smugglers, the child smugglers, the drug smugglers and folks who are coming over with criminal records. Now, the mainstream media want us all to believe, Jesse, that the President thinks everybody who wants to come here is a bad person. No, he doesn't. In fact, the President says constantly he wants people to come here, but come here legally. Be - add to the list of the 33 million people who have come to this country, immigrated here legally over the years, because we are so generous and welcoming. But, if anyone is smuggling a child, if anyone is smuggling drugs, if people are coming here for nefarious reasons, if they're MS-13 gang members, you know that number is not zero, not even close to zero. So people ought to get off their high horses and focus on what this is. Border security as a national security.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right, I want to switch gears to Nancy Pelosi. I guess, your new compadre over there, you're going to have to be dealing with her quite a lot in the next two years at the most, I would say. This is what she did the other day. She actually scolded the media. Listen to this scolding.

utterances.speaker: REP. NANCY PELOSI, D-CALIF.
utterances.utterance: I wish that the press would spend a lot more time on what we need to do here to meet the needs of American people, instead of morning, noon and night allegations against the President. I think you'd have more viewers or readers if we would address concerns that people have rather than just this ongoing, ongoing coverage of what's current with the President from one day to the next.

utterances.speaker: CONWAY
utterances.utterance: That is remarkable.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Is stealing your job, Kellyanne? I mean she sounds exactly like a Republican.

utterances.speaker: CONWAY
utterances.utterance: She does, and indeed she sounds like me who's always talking about not biased coverage because that's easy to see where you want to see it, but in complete coverage. We're not having policy discussions. I've tried to have some this week on a competitor network who doesn't do as well as your network because I like to get the President's message out to different audiences and just get shut down and constantly interrupted when I try to talk about policy. It's that you're deflecting, diverting, pivoting. No, I actually want people to have news they can use. Let's make sure our veterans know what's available to them. Let's make sure workforce development measures and all these opportunities people have to get one of those seven million Trump created jobs that they know about it, that they understand what it means to be one of the 30 million Americans that still doesn't have health insurance, eight and a half years after Obamacare was passed. We want people to have news they can use, not everybody's opinion which of course is not news. But when Pelosi says that, she sounds an awful like a lot like, Jesse, also those Democrats who are saying, "No, no. We're not talking about indictment and impeachment. No, no, no. We're going to work on infrastructure," okay, I'm going to hold them to it. Impeachment, no, out; infrastructure, in. Great. Let's work. We have a builder here in the White House, let's work and build projects.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, let's work together.

utterances.speaker: CONWAY
utterances.utterance: Let's do it together. Let's create those jobs and build stuff and repair the dams and the bridges and the water mains that break and everything else.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, water mains breaking all of over New York City but I blame Bill de Blasio for that.

utterances.speaker: CONWAY
utterances.utterance: I know.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Someone else has been making a lot of sense on the left. I mean, I can't even believe it. Something - something is happening here. Claire McCaskill had a little advice for the Democratic Party. It sounds similar. Let's listen.

utterances.speaker: SEN. CLAIRE MCCASKILL, D-MO.
utterances.utterance: One of the mistakes that we make as a party is spending too much time talking about the gender thing, but we are a party of all kinds of people and, you know, white men, white working-class men have traditionally been a huge part of our party. We have lost a lot of them and one of those reasons is we've had a tendency to talk maybe too much about gender.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oh, so Claire is saying Democrats, "Stop playing the gender card." Kellyanne, thirty seconds, all yours. Go ahead.

utterances.speaker: CONWAY
utterances.utterance: They usually - they usually only discover this, Jesse, after they lose.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right, I'm sure it's a coincidence.

utterances.speaker: CONWAY
utterances.utterance: But it's part of why she lost, because she's running for re-election in Missouri, but amidst the Democratic Party that's veering so far to the left, they can't even reach the middle if they stretch their arms out. Also, I'll remind you that Senator McCaskill told your colleague Brett Baier in an interview on Fox News on October 29th, she thought the President - she used every tool at his disposal to try to secure that border. She was 100% with - she backs him up. That was to try to mollify some of those - many of those Trump voters in her state, a state he carried by 19 points and she just lost. But she lost not just because she's wrong on the issues, but because people look up and they see Democrat now and they know that you're for socialized medicine and she, of course voted against Brett Kavanaugh.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, that was the dagger I think.

utterances.speaker: CONWAY
utterances.utterance: And lost her seat also. But also, she says, look, if the President tapped into the frustration and anger of many voters who feel like their work is not being dignified in her state of Missouri, manufacturers, there are miners, construction and those jobs are way up as is the confidence levels.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right, Kellyanne. Merry Christmas.

utterances.speaker: CONWAY
utterances.utterance: Thank, you, Jesse. Merry Christmas. God bless.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Have a good one.

utterances.speaker: CONWAY
utterances.utterance: Take care.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right, Michael Cohen, the President's former attorney breaking his silence after being sentenced to three years in prison claiming he was only acting at the direction of Mr. Trump.

utterances.speaker: MICHAEL COHEN, FORMER ATTORNEY TO DONALD TRUMP
utterances.utterance: Nothing at the Trump Organization was ever done unless it was to run through Mr. Trump He directed me to make the payments, he directed me to become involved in these matters. The man doesn't tell the truth and it's sad that I should take responsibility for his dirty deeds.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Now, the President says otherwise.

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.utterance: I never directed him to do anything wrong. Whatever he did, he did on his own. He's a lawyer a lawyer, a lawyer who represents a client is supposed to do the right thing. That's why you pay them a lot of money.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Hans Von Spakovsky, is a senior legal fellow at Heritage Foundation and a former Department of Justice official under President George W. Bush. He believes Cohen did not violate campaign finance laws and neither did the President. He joins me now. Hans, this is a really hot article. Rudy has been forwarding it. The President has been waving it around in the air. I've been talking about it on "The Five" all week. I claim all the credit. I mean, I thought of this idea of course for writing it. In simple terms because we're going to be talking about this probably for the next two years, was this payment to Stormy Daniels illegal before the election. You say, the Federal Election Commission, the Federal Election Campaign Act would say no, it's perfectly legal.

utterances.speaker: HANS VON SPAKOVSKY, SENIOR LEGAL FELLOW, HERITAGE FOUNDATION
utterances.utterance: Yes, and the reason is this. You can't use campaign funds to pay personal or business expenses. You can only use campaign funds to pay campaign related expenses.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: SPAKOVSKY
utterances.utterance: And the FEC - the FEC has said in the past that this kind of a payment, a hush money payment, that's a personal expense that's not related to your campaign.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And it was absolutely paid for by Trump, not the campaign.

utterances.speaker: SPAKOVSKY
utterances.utterance: No, that's right and the reason we know that the FEC would not consider this to be a campaign related expense and that's important because if it's not, then all the rules and regulations and Federal law don't apply. But remember, the Justice Department tried to actually make the same argument once before when they prosecuted or tried to prosecute John Edwards, their actual contributors - contributors were making payments to his mistress who was working for the campaign.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: SPAKOVSKY
utterances.utterance: A jury did - a jury didn't buy it, but the FEC also didn't. They audited the Edwards campaign and said these are not campaign related expenses.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right, now so let's just put this into perspective now. If you're in Congress and we know Congress has this slush fund which pays out sexual harassment, sexual misconduct settlements that you know require people to hush up afterwards, they run for re-election every two years. I mean, it's in the window of a campaign of course, millions of dollars is going out. That's taxpayer money. That's not being reported on FEC filings. So what's the difference?

utterances.speaker: SPAKOVSKY
utterances.utterance: No. No, in fact, if you take to the extreme this weird theory that the U.S. Attorney in New York has, yes, all of these members of Congress are using taxpayer funds to pay for campaign related expenses, which I think is very problematic.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Exactly. I mean, if you just give that argument right there, it is game over. I just don't see how people, because everybody on the left is saying, "Oh you know what, he pled to a campaign finance violation. That's it. The President is now on the hook and let's impeach." You're saying, you don't see any evidence in in the case histories and these acts, I mean, you have codes here you cite and I want everybody to read this article by Hans. "Trump's ex lawyer didn't violate campaign finance laws and neither did the President." It's all over the Internet, you can't even spend money. I mean, what if you got a haircut before the election? I mean, out of your personal wallet. I mean, is that a campaign expense, if you don't report it?

utterances.speaker: SPAKOVSKY
utterances.utterance: Well, look under that theory it is. I mean, I'll give you another quick example. Look, if you don't pay the mortgage payments on your house and the bank forecloses in the middle of your campaign, obviously, that's going to hurt your reputation and may influence the outcome of the election. But that's still not a campaign related expense. That's something you have to pay out of your own funds, you can't use campaign money to do it. And by the way, if in fact, a candidate were to use campaign funds to pay off for example a mistress, I can guarantee you, the FEC would be going after them saying, "You used campaign funds for personal expenses."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right. All right, Hans. There it is. I suggest every Democrat in the country read this article. We can all calm down. Thank you very much.

utterances.speaker: SPAKOVSKY
utterances.utterance: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Coming up, Lara Trump getting ready for her first splash into "Watters' World," and speaking of "Watters' World."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What was Hillary's greatest accomplishment as Secretary of State?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Former FBI Director James Comey heading back to Capitol Hill, Monday for more closed-door testimony about his role in the Russia investigation. Recently, Comey admitted he personally made the decision to send agents to the White House to interview Mike Flynn which eventually led to charges against the former National Security adviser.

utterances.speaker: JAMES COMEY, FORMER FBI DIRECTOR
utterances.utterance: Something I probably wouldn't have done or maybe gotten away with in a more organized investigation, a more organized administration in the George W. Bush administration for example or the Obama administration. So if the FBI wanted to send agents into the White House itself to interview a senior official, you would work through the White House Counsel and there'll be discussions and approvals and who would be there and I thought it's early enough, let's just send a couple of guys over.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Here to react, Wisconsin Congressman, Sean Duffy and Florida Congressman, Matt Gaetz who is going to question Comey on Monday. I mean, Matt, this guy is basically saying he took advantage of the disorganization in the Trump White House and really went after and kind of set up Mike Flynn. If this is about Russia, why isn't he going after Russians? Why is he trying to tee up Americans?

utterances.speaker: REP. MATT GAETZ, R-FLA.
utterances.utterance: Well, thanks for having me on, Jesse, though I will say I think this is the first time I've been the third most handsome person on any Fox broadcast with you and Duffy.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oh, thank you. You know what? Duffy takes the cake though, I mean, look at that hair.

utterances.speaker: REP. SEAN DUFFY, R-WIS.
utterances.utterance: Yes, yes, yes. Oh come on.

utterances.speaker: GAETZ
utterances.utterance: When you - yes, he's probably going to fire his comm staff for putting on him along with us, but when it comes to Comey, I mean, you don't typically use the language "something I got away with" to describe something that is proper and good like you never go home and say, "Hey, I got away with making it home before curfew." I mean, usually, getting away with things that are not right are not proper and this will be the second time we bring Comey in, so he'll - it'll be like deja vu, but with all of the amnesia. It's kind of like when you combine deja vu with amnesia, maybe he'll forget all of the things that that you know he thought he was expected to tell us, I don't know --

utterances.speaker: GAETZ
utterances.utterance: Yes, it's amazing, he said, "I don't know, I don't remember, I forget," so many times and for someone that basically investigated both Presidential candidates at the same time within a year of each other and when you ask him a question about it, he doesn't know, Congressman Duffy. Yes, I thought he was supposed to be the smartest guy in the room with the most integrity.

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.utterance: Yes, the guy has a photographic memory as well, but here, there's only one of two choices. Either - this is the biggest investigation that he has in his tenure as the FBI. He's going to investigate a Presidential candidate Donald Trump and then the President Donald Trump. Here he comes to Congress and basically he's a bumbling idiot, doesn't know anything that happened and so we conclude, one of two things. One, either he's stupid or he's lying to Congress. But you can't come in and say "I don't recall or know any of the facts around the largest investigation that I've ever done in my tenure as the FBI director." It's laughable.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right and now, we're hearing Congressman Gaetz about these after-action reports that were written about the Flynn interview. They were written six months after the fact which is extremely fishy and we already know that they went in there without a lawyer present for Flynn. They tried to kind of coax him and kind of keep him relaxed and keep him loose and they had what he said to the Russian Ambassador printed out, he didn't contradict anything. They never thought he was lying. How is he facing any time at this point? I don't get it.

utterances.speaker: GAETZ
utterances.utterance: I think President Trump should pardon Michael Flynn because he's not being called to account for any bad actions he committed with malice. It's largely a consequence of not remembering something or perhaps stating something in a different context. Even Comey said that there was no indicia of lying when Flynn originally met with these folks. Now, Jesse, compare that to Hillary Clinton who had nine lawyers present. Several of her lawyers that were present were actually fact witnesses that should not have been there. So for him for, you know, Hillary Clinton, they roll out the red carpet, they paved the yellow brick road to no consequence, but yet with Michael Flynn, someone who didn't even indicate that he was lying according to James Comey, he's facing serious consequences, and I think the President could do right for justice by pardoning Michael Flynn.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right, I'm glad you brought up in the Clinton investigation - one second, I'm glad you brought that up, Congressman Duffy, because I want to ask you about this. We remember the time when everybody was trying to find these Page-Strzok e-mails and texts and there's like this right six month gap where they couldn't find them at a very critical stage of the investigation. Well, finally the - I guess, Inspector General issued a report and said, you know what, we lost them when we they turned - one-one device they couldn't find, the other couple of devices they said were wiped clean. I think Mueller might have wiped one, the FBI wiped the other. Is that standard procedure?

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.utterance: Of course it's not standard procedure. They should have retained those cell phones and the records of the texts between Strzok and Page, but they didn't. But I think what you see, Jesse, is an utter disregard and respect for the process and the law, number one. But number two, I think the FBI has such contempt for Donald Trump winning this election which is basically a contempt for the American people who elected him. They were willing to twist and contort the laws to actually try to prosecute him and implement that insurance plan to make sure that the electorate didn't have its way, that the FBI and the liberal progressive elites got their way to take Donald Trump out. And so whether it's the Russian investigation, whether it's collusion or campaign finance laws, they won't stop not looking for the truth. They won't stop until they take out Donald Trump.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And Congressman Gaetz, we are just hearing about Hillary. She said under oath that she did the e-mail server for convenience and she also blamed her husband, Bill Clinton. It wouldn't be the first time she blamed her husband for trouble. I'll give you the last word.

utterances.speaker: GAETZ
utterances.utterance: Yes, you don't typically bleach something inadvertently. With Hillary Clinton --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oops, I bleached it.

utterances.speaker: GAETZ
utterances.utterance: Yes, that's something that you typically do with technology and so I think that with Hillary Clinton, you have someone who just fundamentally believed that the rules didn't apply to her and you can understand why. For the Clintons, for decades, they've been able to evade consequence and have things kind of tilt in their favor and it really is unfortunate that we didn't do more in this Congress to drill down, but I think there's more to come. Michael Horowitz is going to give additional reports on the media's influence and the FBI leaking stories and getting improper benefits as a result, so I think we'll see even more about how we can drain the swamp and get rid of some of the deep state entities that are working against our President.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right, that sounds pretty juicy. All right, guys, I've got to run. The three best-looking guys on television right now. I have to say goodbye.

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.utterance: You have the best hair, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: We'll see you later. Thank you very much. Coming up, Lara Trump taking her "Watters' World" debut and later, our body language expert analyzes the Trump-Pelosi-Schumer meeting. Wait until you hear what she has to say.

utterances.speaker: ANITA VOGEL, CORRESPONDENT, FOX NEWS
utterances.utterance: Live from "America's News headquarters," I'm Anita Vogel. President Trump addressing reporters a short time ago at the White House where the Congressional ball was held; the President praising Friday's Obamacare ruling. A Federal judge in Texas struck down the law calling it unconstitutional on the eve of the signup deadline for 2019 coverage. Here's President Trump from earlier tonight.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.utterance: I believe we're going to get really good healthcare. Exciting things happened over the last 24 hours. If the Republicans and the Democrats get together, we are going to end up with incredible healthcare which is the way it should have been from day one and it's going to happen. It now has a chance to happen.

utterances.speaker: VOGEL
utterances.utterance: Democrats have pledged to fight the ruling. This means the legal battle is likely headed to the Supreme Court, yet again. I'm Anita Vogel, now back to "Watters' World."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Despite the media and Democrats constantly attacking President Trump for basically everything he does these days, the barrage of bad news is not affecting voters. A recent Fox News poll shows the President now has a 46% job approval rating. That's up about points from a year ago, but will that high approval rating help President Trump win reelection. Joining me now, the President's daughter-in-law and senior advisor for the Trump 2020 campaign, Lara Trump. Lara, welcome to "Watters' World."

utterances.speaker: LARA TRUMP, DAUGHTER-IN-LAW OF DONALD TRUMP
utterances.utterance: Thank you. Thanks for having me. It's about time, I think.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It is about time. I blame my staff.

utterances.speaker: L. TRUMP
utterances.utterance: You can always blame them, but --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's true and I always do. Alright, so the President now about 46%. It's pretty good considering the attacks that he's weathered over the last two years. Do you guys pay attention to numbers like that or not?

utterances.speaker: L. TRUMP
utterances.utterance: If we paid attention to numbers, then we would have understood that Donald Trump had a 1% chance on Election Day to actually win in 2016. I have never believed polls, Jesse. I saw throughout the campaign in 2016 how they were constantly wrong. I saw even leading up to the midterms how I don't think they were completely accurate as we went into the midterms, so, we of course see them and we take note.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Do you guys have internal polling that you look at ...

utterances.speaker: L. TRUMP
utterances.utterance: We do.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: ... that differs from ...

utterances.speaker: L. TRUMP
utterances.utterance: We absolutely do.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: ... the mainstream media polling a little bit?

utterances.speaker: L. TRUMP
utterances.utterance: And it is different.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It is different.

utterances.speaker: L. TRUMP
utterances.utterance: It is very different and I think what we've seen with polls is that people are not always truthful when it comes to supporting President Trump.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Why do you think that is?

utterances.speaker: L. TRUMP
utterances.utterance: Well, it's because the because the media makes you feel like there's something wrong with you or it's a bad thing to support a President who will go down in history as one of the greatest our country has ever had.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, because they always say that, you know, Republican voters especially Donald Trump voters, they don't talk to the exit polling people. They hang up the phone when it's you know Reuters calls and asks of what they think of the President and maybe people don't want to say to their neighbor, "Oh, yes. I'm voting for President Trump for re-election." Do you think it's because the media has conditioned Americans to feel guilty about supporting this President? Because they think he's so controversial?

utterances.speaker: L. TRUMP
utterances.utterance: Well, I think that's a definite component of it. I think that the media makes you feel like there's something wrong with you if you have very vocal support for this President. You see the way they talk about Trump supporters at Trump rallies and the negative things that get said about them. You see people going out to have a nice dinner that get accosted by people, thanks to people like Maxine Waters telling you that you should get up in their face and kick them when they're down like Eric Holder. I think that there is some really scary stuff that's being said and it really does make it hard sometimes to voice your support for a great President.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: When someone threw a drink in my face on night after I was a little rowdy when the President won Wisconsin and Michigan, it was a free drink. That's how I took it.

utterances.speaker: L. TRUMP
utterances.utterance: There you go.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right so re-election, Harris Faulkner just interviewed the President and asked about some Republicans potentially primary-ing him. Here's what he had to say.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS FAULKNER, HOST
utterances.utterance: I'm going bring up John Kasich and I'm going to bring up Arizona Senator Jeff Flake because they say they may run against you in 2020. Kasich or Flake?

utterances.speaker: D. TRUMP
utterances.utterance: I hope so. I think we have the greatest base in the history of politics. I have people that I love and that love me frankly that includes a lot of women. I've got a tremendous percentage of women last time. Remember I wasn't going to get women. I wasn't going to --

utterances.speaker: FAULKNER
utterances.utterance: I interviewed some of the women for Trump.

utterances.speaker: D. TRUMP
utterances.utterance: Yes, I've got women that - they are the greatest and I have tremendous women support.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: We'll get to the women in a second, but do you believe the President really wants Flake and Kasich to primary him?

utterances.speaker: L. TRUMP
utterances.utterance: Well, I don't think it's going to happen.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You don't.

utterances.speaker: L. TRUMP
utterances.utterance: I think that - what a waste of money. This is a President who is easily going to win re-election, Jesse. I think based on the great job that he's doing, he is his best commercial because everything he does every day that is so beneficial for people across this country is the reason that I think he's going to win by more in 2020 than he even did in 2016.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, I think it's a fantasy if those two try to primary him. It's a fool's errand. So he's saying that he has tremendous female support. He won the majority of white women in 2016, but overall, you keep hearing about these suburban college-educated female voters that he really needs to have come out for him more enthusiastically than they did in 2016. Are you guys paying attention to that voting group?

utterances.speaker: L. TRUMP
utterances.utterance: Oh, certainly. We pay attention to all voting groups because every person in this country has the right to one vote and we want everyone to get out there and vote.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Do you have a strategy to really turn out those women?

utterances.speaker: L. TRUMP
utterances.utterance: Well, I think again, the President is going to do the best job of that himself and I think a lot of it is reminding women what this President has accomplished in this country, why it's a better future for them, why there are more opportunities for them. Look at female unemployment in this country. The lowest it's been in like 60 years or something. I'm sure we'll get to lowest in all time at some point. It's a safer country, thanks to Donald Trump. It's a better country for women with children and thanks to Donald Trump.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So safety and prosperity.

utterances.speaker: L. TRUMP
utterances.utterance: I mean I think ...

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Those are the things you're hitting with women.

utterances.speaker: L. TRUMP
utterances.utterance: When you have more money in your pocket when it's a better world for your child out there, you want to see that continue. You don't want to go back the other way.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: For your purse. More money in your purse.

utterances.speaker: L. TRUMP
utterances.utterance: In your wallet or your purse, however you want to go.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Wallet or your purse. That's right. Okay, Melania Trump was just on "Hannity" you know, obviously she's got to go on "Hannity." It's the only show to go on and that she was asked about some of the attacks that she faces through the media. I think worse than any other First Lady that I've ever seen. I'm only 40 though, so it's not that big of a length. So this is what she said and how she responded.

utterances.speaker: MELANIA TRUMP, FIRST LADY
utterances.utterance: I would say the opportunists who are using my name or my family name to advance themselves from comedians to journalists to performers, book writers --

utterances.speaker: SEAN HANNITY, HOST
utterances.utterance: Does hurt it?

utterances.speaker: M. TRUMP
utterances.utterance: It doesn't hurt. The problem is they are writing the history and it's not correct.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So if you're in entertainment or if you're in the media and you attack President Trump, instant headline, instant click, instant notoriety. Do you think she has a point about that?

utterances.speaker: L. TRUMP
utterances.utterance: She's a hundred percent correct. First of all, we have a First Lady who is so classy and so wonderful and does such a great job and is such a great representation of this country, of the White House, of everything a First Lady should be. The fact, Jesse, that she's not on every cover of every magazine like other First Ladies have been is crazy to me. She's so gorgeous. She's so elegant, so fashionable but that tells you really all you need to know and she's a hundred percent right. You know, if it weren't for President Donald Trump, what the heck would everybody be talking about out there? Thanks to him, he's keeping so many companies, so many journalists in business.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's true.

utterances.speaker: L. TRUMP
utterances.utterance: We can we can say thank you to the President for that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I hear Eric's not changing any diapers, is that true?

utterances.speaker: L. TRUMP
utterances.utterance: Every now and again. Every now and again.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Now and again. All right, tell him I told him to change one once in a while.

utterances.speaker: L. TRUMP
utterances.utterance: Will do.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Thank you very much, Lara.

utterances.speaker: L. TRUMP
utterances.utterance: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right, up next Diamond and Silk, everybody, stick around. There seems to be an uptick in the mainstream media using homophobic slurs to attack political figures mostly centrally, MSNBC's Mika Brzezinski, watch.

utterances.speaker: MIKA BRZEZINSKI, HOST, MSNBC
utterances.utterance: Why doesn't Mike Pompeo care right now? Are the pathetic deflections that we just heard when he appeared on "Fox & Friends," is that a patriot speaking or a wannabe dictator's butt boy? I'm dead serious. I'm asking. Are these the words of a patriot?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Whoa. Mika did apologize a few days later, but is it too little too late? Here with their reaction, Diamond and Silk all on set, must be my lucky day.

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND, VIDEO BLOGGER
utterances.utterance: Yes, it is.

utterances.speaker: SILK, VIDEO BLOGGER
utterances.utterance: Yes, it is, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right, so what do you think about Mika, you know, it sounds like she almost planned to say that. It didn't seem like it rolled off the tip of her tongue?

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.utterance: Well, you know, she feels like she can get away with anything, that's how the Liberals - they act like they can get away with saying anything and it's okay.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They usually do.

utterances.speaker: SILK
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.utterance: And they do because she's not fired. They haven't reprimanded her and yes, her apology is a little too late.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Imagine if I said "butt boy."

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.utterance: You are out of here.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Goodbye, "Watters' World." It should be your last appearance.

utterances.speaker: SILK
utterances.utterance: You're absolutely right, and it lets me know also that they've been doing this type of talk behind closed doors anyway because you are what you think. So it just came right out of her tongue.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Wow, then I must be a hamburger because I'm starving.

utterances.speaker: SILK
utterances.utterance: All right now.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Also, I just - we have to say ten years ago, Kevin Hart said what he said about gay people and he had to leave hosting the Oscars and she didn't leave anything. It just seems like a little bit of a double standard. It really depends who you are as opposed to what you can get away with. But let's move on. Nancy Pelosi, your favorite Democrat had this to say, let's roll it.

utterances.speaker: PELOSI
utterances.utterance: It's really unfortunate that the President has decided that he would shut down government. He is taking full responsibility for the Trump shutdown. Perhaps he doesn't understand people need their paychecks. Maybe that's not the life he leads.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: People need their crumbs, right?

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.utterance: Okay, you know that's what she said.

utterances.speaker: SILK
utterances.utterance: That's what she said.

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.utterance: People are thriving in this country.

utterances.speaker: SILK
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.utterance: So the paycheck is not the problem. The problem is security.

utterances.speaker: SILK
utterances.utterance: Right. That's right.

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.utterance: We want our border security, and if you can live behind your wall, Miss Nancy Pelosi, then why is - are you having a problem with funding the wall for the United States of America. I'm tired of them funding illegal aliens. I'm tired of them funding sanctuary cities. It's time to fund the wall, so that you can keep the American people safe.

utterances.speaker: SILK
utterances.utterance: And I'm getting a little bit of sick and tired of these individuals that us, taxpayers, we pay them. We're actually their boss for them to go and be in government to work for we, the American people. If they don't want to work for we, the American people, then shut the government down.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You know what I'm thinking, when they do shutdown, Nancy probably still gets paid, right?

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.utterance: Absolutely.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I bet she still gets a paycheck.

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.utterance: Yes, behind her vineyard. Yes, she is still going to get a paycheck.

utterances.speaker: SILK
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.utterance: Absolutely, but it's going to call them to the table. It's going to force them to work for the people. They ran on we're going do this, we're going to do that.

utterances.speaker: SILK
utterances.utterance: That's right.

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.utterance: You need to do your job and if you can't do your job, goodbye.

utterances.speaker: SILK
utterances.utterance: And stop allowing them to hoodwink us. You know, they ran on changing or doing something or redoing something with healthcare because they gave us Obamacare and have done absolutely nothing about it. This is exactly what the Democrats do. They like to hoodwink people, make you think they're going to do this for you when they do nothing but fill you a bill of empty promises.

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.utterance: They all talk and no action.

utterances.speaker: SILK
utterances.utterance: That's right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right, speaking of Maxine Waters. A lot of talk, a lot a lot of talk from her recently. This again is about her favorite topic, impeachment. Go ahead.

utterances.speaker: REP. MAXINE WATERS, D-CALIF.
utterances.utterance: I believe that this President is dangerous. I think he has undermined our democracy. I think he's aligned himself with the enemy, with Putin. He loves dictators and I believe that he certainly qualifies for impeachment.

utterances.speaker: D. TRUMP
utterances.utterance: It's called Presidential harassment. The President of your country is doing a great job, but he's being harassed. It's Presidential harassment.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Presidential harassment. Do you think that's what this is? This impeachment deal?

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.utterance: That's exactly what it is.

utterances.speaker: SILK
utterances.utterance: That's right.

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.utterance: You know, there's a slush fund up there with Congress where they're paying off people that have been - these congressmen that have been accused of sexual harassment or sexual misconduct.

utterances.speaker: SILK
utterances.utterance: That's right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.utterance: Or sexual misconduct.

utterances.speaker: SILK
utterances.utterance: That's right.

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.utterance: They are paying them off with our tax dollars.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, they are.

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.utterance: What about that slush fund? Why don't you - why don't Maxine Waters go and harass those people. We want to see the names of these Congress men and women or whoever who are accused of these --

utterances.speaker: SILK
utterances.utterance: That's right. Who did we pay?

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.utterance: We need to see that. I am tired of them talking I'm talking about impeachment. Impeach him for what? For giving us a booming economy? That's why you want to impeach him?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: There's no money for the wall, but there's money to pay off all the people that Congress harassed.

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.utterance: There you go.

utterances.speaker: SILK
utterances.utterance: That's right, and it's our taxpayers' money that's doing it. We can use that money to fund the wall.

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.utterance: And what are you going to impeach him on? Or impeach him for? If we're going to impeach anybody, let's start with her because we went to her district.

utterances.speaker: SILK
utterances.utterance: We went to her district.

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.utterance: It's a hot mess.

utterances.speaker: SILK
utterances.utterance: That's right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right, Diamond and Silk, in studio, "Chitchat Tour" launching next year, don't miss it.

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SILK
utterances.utterance: Yes. Don't miss it, sweetie.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right, up next, a body language expert breaks down what really happened at the Trump-Pelosi-Schumer meeting. Stick to it. President Trump opening his contentious meeting on wall funding with Nancy Pelosi and Chuck Schumer to the public. The President telling Schumer he would own a government shutdown if that's what it took to get his wall.

utterances.speaker: D. TRUMP
utterances.utterance: The last time, Chuck, you shut it down.

utterances.speaker: SEN. CHUCK SCHUMER, D-N.Y.
utterances.utterance: No, no, no.

utterances.speaker: D. TRUMP
utterances.utterance: And then you opened it ...

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.utterance: Many times.

utterances.speaker: D. TRUMP
utterances.utterance: ... very quickly. I don't want to do what you did.

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.utterance: Twenty times you have called for - I will shut down the government, if I don't get my wall. None of us --

utterances.speaker: D. TRUMP
utterances.utterance: You want to know something? SCHUMER: You've said it.

utterances.speaker: D. TRUMP
utterances.utterance: Okay, you want to put that on my --

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.utterance: You said it.

utterances.speaker: D. TRUMP
utterances.utterance: I'll take it.

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.utterance: Okay, good.

utterances.speaker: D. TRUMP
utterances.utterance: You know what I'll say, yes, if we don't get what we want, one way or the other whether it's through you, through a military, through anything you want to call, I will shut down the government.

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.utterance: Okay, absolutely, no.

utterances.speaker: D. TRUMP
utterances.utterance: And I am proud and I'll tell you what ...

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.utterance: We disagree.

utterances.speaker: D. TRUMP
utterances.utterance: I am proud to shut down government for border security, Chuck.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: A lot going on right there, particularly with the body language, so expert Tonya Reiman is here to help us out. Hey Tonya.

utterances.speaker: TONYA REIMAN, BODY LANGUAGE EXPERT
utterances.utterance: Hey, how are you?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Very good. All right, let's take a look and slow this down of this interaction between crying Chuck and the President. All right, what are we seeing here?

utterances.speaker: REIMAN
utterances.utterance: Okay, so obviously, we know, President Trump loves to use his hands and he uses them to frame his words, so when you're watching him -- Okay, here's the interesting thing. You see how he just adjusted his jacket.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: REIMAN
utterances.utterance: This is the one time that you see him get nervous. When he adjusts his jacket, that's his little bit of discomfort coming through, but here comes the New York. Okay, so he leans forward, gets closer to Schumer and then the only other pacifying gesture he does is he holds his hand like this. So when you hold your hand like this and you see Schumer is doing the same thing, this is something that builds comfort and it also puts a blockage between the two of us.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's like a soothing.

utterances.speaker: REIMAN
utterances.utterance: Right, not only that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What's he doing here? Now, he's - oh, with the finger.

utterances.speaker: REIMAN
utterances.utterance: Oh, yes, that's you and Nancy, right? And then again, the stop sign. This is what he's famous for like it's not your turn to talk, it's my turn to talk. Listen to what I'm saying. So a lot has been made also about Schumer with his posture. He's a slouch to begin with. He just has terrible posture. When he got serious though, he lifted himself back up and then went right back into that position. So I love the fact that Trump was so into like right getting into --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, he's right up in Chuck's face.

utterances.speaker: REIMAN
utterances.utterance: Yes, there was no go about.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Now, also, there was some interesting kind of go-between between Nancy Pelosi and the President. Let's watch that.

utterances.speaker: D. TRUMP
utterances.utterance: You know, Nancy is in a situation where it's not easy for her to talk right now and I understand that and I fully understand that. We're going to have a good discussion and we're going to see what happens. But we have to have border security.

utterances.speaker: PELOSI
utterances.utterance: Mr. President, please characterize the strength that I bring for this meeting as the leader of the House Democrats who just won a big victory.

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.utterance: Elections have consequences, Mr. President. PELOSI; Let me just say it.

utterances.speaker: D. TRUMP
utterances.utterance: That's right and that's why the country is doing so well.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right, so the President starts off and let's look at what he's doing here. He starts off kind of talking for Nancy.

utterances.speaker: REIMAN
utterances.utterance: Okay, look at the steeple.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, what is the steeple when the President does that?

utterances.speaker: REIMAN
utterances.utterance: This is what his go-to position, but a steeple is typically considered to be one of power, so this is his go-to posture.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Okay, got it.

utterances.speaker: REIMAN
utterances.utterance: What was interesting is you see Nancy, she gets very offended and she - don't speak for me. This is a woman no matter you like her or dislike her, she is not afraid of Trump.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: She's doing a lot of aggressive hand motions.

utterances.speaker: REIMAN
utterances.utterance: Yes, because she is not afraid. She is like "don't speak for me.” She came in to have a meeting and gets frustrated because you see Schumer looking at everybody who's in the crowd. You see Trump talking to the crowd and Pence just sitting there. So Pelosi is getting annoyed because she's like "I want to have a dialogue" and that's when she starts to turn around and talk to other people.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Okay, let's look at Pence here. I mean, what is Pence doing the whole time, just like this? What does that - I mean, he's just like "get me out of here."

utterances.speaker: REIMAN
utterances.utterance: Here's the interesting thing. If you watch him, not only did he lean back in his chair which is a distancing thing. We do that we want --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So he doesn't want any part of this.

utterances.speaker: REIMAN
utterances.utterance: Right, but not only that. He also sways back and forth depending who he agrees with at any given moment.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He might be agreeing with Nancy.

utterances.speaker: REIMAN
utterances.utterance: Yes, he might just not be agreeing with Trump. There's a difference. It doesn't mean he's agreeing with Nancy.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Very interesting.

utterances.speaker: REIMAN
utterances.utterance: And if you watch him, he does fidget. The foot will start to jazz occasionally.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Jazz foot.

utterances.speaker: REIMAN
utterances.utterance: Yes, and he does not hold eye contact really with anyone. He says what's called an extended eye closure quite often and that's his way of like shutting this out because he truly does not want to be there and it's quite evident.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right. Tonya Reiman, everybody. Thank you very much.

utterances.speaker: REIMAN
utterances.utterance: Thank you.

utterances.utterance: Actually that is a good question.

utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.utterance: You want her to be transparent?
